awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  High-Speed Indoor Wireless Networking  Using Visible Light Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is bringing numerous economic and social benefits to the public: advance the security of information and communication, decrease public health risk, and overall increase the quality of life all around the world. VLC has the potential to significantly increase the speed of Internet connection in multiuser indoor environments due to the broad bandwidth of the visible light. Commercializing the VLC technology will not only be a big step toward energy saving and provide stronger justification and desire for implementing economical LED systems, but also will increase the speed and security of wireless data communications. It will offer a huge energy saving for the nation since energy is already used for lighting, and thus does not require separate expenditure for communications. It will also increase the quality of life for those who are concerned about the impacts of Wi-Fi on their health, and any group of people including children and pregnant women can use it for Internet connection without any concern about the effect of electromagnetic waves. VLC can replace the controversial Wi-Fi technology in schools, hospitals, kindergartens and any other place that health issues are of major concerns.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project is to develop the technology for visible light communication (VLC) system that achieves high data-rates using low-cost commercial light emitting diodes (LED). VLC is a potential alternative data communication technique for wireless applications that uses optical energy to provide simultaneously lighting needs and data transmission. The idea in this technology is to transmit the data using the lighting systems that are already used for the illumination of indoor environments. Spectrally efficient coding and modulation techniques with dimming feature support will be developed based on combinatorial designs to modulate LEDs. Multi-input multi-output (MIMO) will be explored to increase the transmission speeds since each user receives signals from multiple LEDs. Solutions to address technical problems of using LEDs intended for lighting in commercial VLC systems, such as LED heating, LED nonlinearity and controlling large LED-arrays with low-cost small circuits will be explored. The techniques developed in the Phase I of this proposal can also be employed along with faster but more expensive LEDs and photo-detectors to achieve Gbps streaming in VLC systems. Furthermore, tri-chromatic LEDs can be used to achieve a three-fold increase in the data-rate by modulating each color independently.

por.por_cntn:
I.        Proof of Technical Concept with Prototyping

The prototype includes a desk lamp as access point (AP) and a user device (device). The lamp emits modulated light operating not only as an lighting source but also as a data pipeline. The user device emits Infrared (IR) light for uplink traffic.  Both AP and device are equipped with photodiodes to receive light signals.

Compared to major competitors, who emphasize on the transmission speed by setting up the system in “ideal” environment such as fully dark room, short distance between transmitter and receiver and etc, our first generation prototype was designed to operate under real world constraints and tested in common office space (5 by 5 by 3 meters), with windows to receive natural sunlight. Meanwhile, the transmitter and receiver are 1 meter apart to emulate common desk lamp setup. The test shows our system provides an illumination that meets lighting standards and is able to maintain high-speed connection under natural background light condition.

No additional energy is spent on generating (radio frequency) RF signal as with Wi-Fi routers. Our modulated signal strictly resides in the visible light domain therefore is also used fully for lighting purposes.

Prototype fully complies with IEEE 802.15.7 standards. The MAC and PHY layer functionalities and frame formats are customized to fit in our point-to-point topology setup. This is achieved by maintaining all the necessary fields in the frame, and choose optional fields that are suitable for our system, such as shorter address field of 16-bit length, turning off beacon transmission etc.

Our VLC system interfaces with existing network, such as Ethernet, seamlessly. Ethernet frames are received at the access point. The traffic then goes through a series of steps to be encapsulated into our proposed VLC frames to add features of media access control, bit error detection, maintaining frame orders, etc. The VLC frames then go through lower digital and analog circuits to be sent out using LEDs. The signal received at user device using photodiode is used to recover the original VLC frames and then processed to recover the Ethernet traffic. By doing this we create a transparent link for the users. Not only it simplifies the setup of the VLC system, but also provides additional management capabilities without the need to work with other links. All the processing is done in the user space software running on Linux and FPGA.

Our system adheres to the OSI architecture guidelines to provide easy maintenance and new features upgrade in the development. These factors allow our product to be added to any existing network environment quickly and efficiently.

Flicker free operation is achieved through: DC current is added to the modulated signals so that the LED is never fully turned off. An idle pattern is transmitted when there is no data to send. Line coding is used to maintain constant average optical power. Besides, IR uplink is chosen to avoid visible light from user device.

We test our prototype by providing user’s PC Internet access. Our prototype allows smooth video streaming and Internet browsing.

Demo video link: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-VZMoTW3FAzQ2lVLUxBZkZPaGc

 II.        Multi-user Access Technique

We develop technique that allows single LED access point to support up to 20 users simultaneously in time and spectrum. The cumulative speed for downlink reaches up to 200 Mbps. The benefit of our technique is low complexity in transmitter and receiver design and therefore lower the cost of equipment.

 III.        Location-Aware Channel Modeling to Handle Fast Line-of-Sight Channel Condition Change such as Shadowing.

Signal equalization and detection rely on the channel estimation. Unlike RF systems, line-of-sight (LOS) part of the VLC channel changes fast due to effects such as shadowing therefore is hard to track. In order to improve accuracy of the VLC channel modeling we propose a binary linear programming model for the LOS channel. The channel model includes link parameters which can be known from the relative location of the user device to the APs. Location information are calculated by two candidate methods.

 IV.        Multi-user Multiple-Input-Multiple-Output based Power Allocation Algorithm

Centralized and distributed power allocation algorithms are developed based on MIMO. The algorithm shows advantages such as high energy efficiency for communication, free from nonlinearity effects from LEDs, no DC bias required, and simple transmitter/receiver structure.

 V.        Outreach Activities

VLNComm has been a strong advocate for the VLC technology and its integration of lighting. On our website: www.vlncomm.com, educational segment with technology updates provides visitors easy and fast way to get familiar with VLC. We further extend our outreach through University of Virginia print media and many other news outlets. We are greatly encouraged by the positive feedback from the media and industry.
